intro: Vaccinium alaternoides var. parvifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaved huckleberry, is a shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes blueberries and cranberries, and is adapted to acidic, well-drained soils. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, followed by edible berries that are dark blue to black in color. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forests and streamside areas. The leaves are lance-shaped and have a dense, leathery texture, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens.
